Message.Title: Why are investors shorting Intel? To make a long story short, no, this short interest isn't warranted!
Message.Msg: Intel Why are investors shorting Intel? The faster-than-expected demise of the personal computer is practically the entire reason why short-sellers have dog piled into Intel. As the overwhelming leader in microprocessors for PC's -- boasting a market share of 85.2% in the first quarter -- Intel has the biggest cliff to contend with if PC sales continue to dip by double digits. Instead, Intel is being forced to spend even more on R&D to align itself to succeed in a cloud-computing based world. These higher expenses are likely to constrain its profits over the next couple of quarters, if not longer. Is this short interest warranted? If you can look beyond 2013, then I feel Intel is an incredibly sound investment that short-sellers would be smart to shy away from. Intel has a real opportunity to become the dominant hardware player in cloud-computing via servers and big data centers. Intel is also playing its hand as the processor of choice in tablets and smartphones, although it's had only minimal success so far in these areas. Even though PCs are slowing, its dominance of the microprocessor market delivers predictable cash flow and a rapidly growing dividend that made Intel a perfect selection for my Basic Needs Portfolio. To make a long story short, no, this short interest isn't warranted! source motley fool

Message.Title: Intel Corporation (NASDAQ:INTC) Moat Is Coming Into Play
Message.Msg: Tech Equipment Stocks: Intel Corporation (NASDAQ:INTC) Moat Is Coming Into Play, ARM Holdings, Advanced Micro Devices, QUALCOMM, Alcatel Lucent by John Beal | Jul 8, 2013 12:07 At the same time as a lot of investors remain focused on Intel Corporation (NASDAQ:INTC) core PC and server processor businesses, the company has been generating more buzz lately about its prospects in the smartphone and tablet chip market. Intel persists to chase after incumbent ARM Holdings plc (ADR) (NASDAQ:ARMH) in mobile processors, other than is making progress on that front. The company’s upcoming “Silvermont” Atom chips will power by a new architecture as well as it will be manufacture at the cutting-edge 22-nm chip fabrication technology, which analysts believe it will increase Intel’s competitiveness in the smartphone and tablet space. Further, it was expected that Intel’s wide moat to come into play, as the company will take advantage of its industry-leading manufacturing assets and aptitude to forcefully refresh its processor architectures in an attempt to surge its presence in the smartphone and tablet processor space. Intel has a broad moat, which stalks from its position as the world’s biggest chip-maker. The firm’s huge scale lets it to invest more in research and development plus in semiconductor manufacturing assets than any other chip firm, which is summarized in Intel’s “tick-tock” strategy. Intel builds a new iteration down Moore’s Law every two years (the tick), whereas it releases a new architecture for its computer microprocessors during the years in between. Intel has the majority advanced semiconductor fabrication technology in the world, with as a minimum a one-year lead in excess of the rest of the industry, which they view as the company’s greatest competitive advantage. It has assisted the firm dominate the PC and server microprocessor space. The significantly, they believe the advantage will as well come into play as Intel attempts to increase head

Message.Title: Intel leads chip stocks down on bearish Citi note
Message.Msg: Intel leads chip stocks down on bearish Citi note Intel Corp. INTC -3.24% led a downswing in the chip sector on Monday morning following a bearish note on the group from Citigroup. In a report, analyst Glen Yeung cut his estimates on Intel and took Qualcomm QCOM -0.61% off the broker's Top Pick's list, citing saturation in the high-end smartphone market for his latter move. Regarding Intel, Yeung wrote that despite the company's efforts to get into more mobile products, "we find it difficult to believe Intel shares will breakout to the upside in light of the poor PC environment and negative estimate revisions," maintaining a hold rating on the stock. Intel shares fell 2.8% while rival AMD AMD -1.65% fell 1.8% and Qualcomm slipped by 0.7%. The Philadelphia Semiconductor Index fell nearly 1% in early trades despite an overall uptick in the broader tech sector. Micron MU -2.87% shares were down more than 2.7% despite Citi leaving the memory chip maker on its Top Picks list.

Topic.Title: The fallacy: PC is dead...

Message.Msg: Business travelers will have a choice for Windows mobility, thin lightweight laptops and Ultrabooks running 64 bit W8.1 or Windows tablets running mostly 32 bit W8.1. Between a 64 bit Ultrabook or 32 bit tablet one is probably better off with the 64 bit Ultrabook because they don't want to have to worry about compatibility differences between W64 and W32 and the carry weight isn't much different. While Intel's new Windows tablets are impressive, desktops, laptops and Ultrabooks are still the devices where most work gets done.

Message.Msg: The article is an expected outcome based on ASSUMPTIONS. The primary assumption that Russ makes is that: 1. the Intel forecasted 2013 revenues (low single digit increase) are correct and do not deteriorate, 2. the Intel forecasted 2013 margins (Q2 of 58% and full year 60%) are correct and do not deteriorate, 3. the Intel costs are extrapolated forward flat His article is saying: Assuming Intel forecasts are right, then this is what we can expect. It is a very good article to walk through to see what Intel is implying will happen. It is also a very good article to use as a model for changing some of the assumptions and recalculating the results. You can use it to model what the analysts are projecting.

Topic.Title: Loving the energy on the board, today. Go get 'em! 30m shares with 4 hours left.

Message.Msg: It doesn't matter if smartphone sales are plateauing. It doesn't matter if tablets sales will outpace PCs in a year. They are all grouped back under one umbrella, the computer. The CPU is strong enough on each device to qualify it as a computer. The metric we need to measure now is screens. Saying the smartphone market has stopped it's rocket trajectory is bad for INTC is like saying the car market is bad for Tesla... because the car market isn't growing like it did 30 years ago. INTC has already locked down 350 million screens in a market of 2.35 billion. Even if the market is static, INTC can still grow marker share (the market is not static and servers weren't even included in the 2.35 billion estimate). Check the open interest in the July puts. Watch for short covering. Earnings are the only song worth listening to, not the day-to-day shill/basher/pumper/spammer nursery rhymes.

Topic.Title: Beware of these analysts: Stacy Rasgon/Romit Shah/James Covello

Message.Msg: CAPEX is a means to an ends and an investment in future production and production efficiency. Don't really understand why analysts always want to distort it into a negative unless their aim is to purposely manipulate the stock. If you look at most of the bear analysts you can see that they all have buy recommendations on ARMH so their bias is pretty clear. INTC has spent a lot of money retooling their factories for 450 MM wafers. They are way out in front on this and this has allowed them to have efficiency that the others don't have. The result will be margin expansion due to increased efficiency. Hard to see that as a negative.

Message.Title: Stock Options Watch: INTC, LEG, ALKS
Message.Msg: Stock Options Watch: INTC, LEG, ALKS By Caitlin Duffy Jul 8, 2013, 1:30 PM Author's Blog INTC – Intel Corp. – Put options purchased on Intel during the final 30 minutes of trading last week have since roughly tripled in value, with shares in the chipmaker down 3.5% at $23.22 on Monday morning. The stock was cut to ‘Underweight’ from ‘Equal-weight’ with a 12-month target price of $20.00 at Evercore Partners this morning. The largest increase in open interest in weekly options on INTC was in the Jul 12 ’13 $23.5 strike puts. Time and sales data indicates more than 4,400 of the $23.5 strike put options were purchased for an average premium of $0.13 apiece on Friday afternoon. The contracts are now changing hands at more than three times that level, with the last-traded price on the contracts at $0.43 each just before midday in New York. Today, some traders appear to be bracing for further weakness in the price of the underlying, buying around 800 of the Jul 12 ’13 $23 strike puts for an average premium of $0.15 each, and picking up around 500 of the $22.5 strike weekly put contracts at an average premium of $0.05 apiece. Intel reports second-quarter earnings next Wednesday

Message.Title: What is PC anyway?
Message.Msg: I thought it's anything that does computing and performs complex tasks. So there are/were Desktops, Notebooks and Netbooks. Now,Ultrabooks, Tablets and newer generation Phones are becoming your computing devices with shorter life span (every 2 year you change your phone. Isn't it?). So desktops (so called PCs) are dead, Notebooks are transformed into Ultrabooks and Tablets and Phones will become powerful computing devices. That's undeniable and even Intel says so. I bought my first desktop for $3000 and today, it's about few hundred dollars but much more powerful. Also, 80% drop in pricing but 100 times faster. Intel didn't exactly die because of this drop. But it expanded it's business in every aspect. This will be next leg up for Intel. That's what today's Bay Trail benchmark confirms. It's transitioning. It looks to me as though Intel is playing it's cards by keeping them close it's chest. Intel probably predicted and transitioned in a planned manner instead of jumping on the ship with everyone else. Of course, they missed first phase of mobile transition (after notebook innovation). May be, wisely so as they didn't want to take a beating with low margin, cheap processor sales. The current phase is where really value starts flowing with people and high speed networks demanding more powerful processing capabilities. ARM will have play defensive as Intel going offense. Enjoy the ride.

Topic.Title: Forbes: "Yes, the ATIV tablets were impressive..."

Message.Msg: Apple will always have their fans and so the Haswell MacBook Airs and soon to be upgraded MacBook Pro with Haswell, will sell extremely well because of the improved resolution and 80% improvement in battery life. On the Windows and Android side, Haswell is really giving computer makers lots of ammunition to get consumers to upgrade the XP and Windows 7 computers. Notebook/Ultrabooks/Hybrids with Haswell, are allowing all-day battery with unheard of graphics resolutions. The ATIV Q and ATIV Book 9 are perfect examples of this. It has only been 2 week since Haswell release and already we are selling some incredible devices...ATIV Q, Dell XPS 11, Sony VAIO Duo 13, etc. We will see even more incredible devices once the Haswell Y series ULV parts (6W SDP) and the ultra ULV parts (4.5W SDP) are released. These should allow for Core process in thin fanless tablet/hybrid designs

Message.Title: there is war going on
Message.Msg: just like I predicted.... what's odd? Apple cutting back orders, Samsung misses due to weak smart phone sales and QCOM target reduced due to smart phone saturation. That seems to contradict AMAT view (AMAT is kind of leading indicator) - is smart not smart enough? It's always good business practice to split the business when possible - someone mentioned Apple using Intel for high end stuff - I think that's a good possibility just for the purpose to put some pressure on TSMC - only an idiot would commit 20, 16 and 10nm business to TSMC without having a back up - there are some phones out there based on Intel 32nm SoC. will they upgrade to 22nm? Applied Materials CEO Mike Splinter told analysts at the chip manufacturing gear supplier's annual investor day that he expects spending to improve next year, driven by demand for more and better smartphones and by the increased complexity of new manufacturing processes being adopted by chipmakers. "When we talk about markets, it's really all about mobile, it's where the growth is," Splinter said on Monday. "There is a war going on between these device makers."
